nodes.text: High public and external debt levels are systematically associated with lower economic growth, and in some cases higher inflation, across countries and history

Dataset and empirical approach: compiled a historical multi-country dataset on central government debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations, supplemented by external debt data and recent series for external debt

Finding for advanced economies (1946–2009 and longer series): when public debt/GDP exceeds roughly 90 percent, median GDP growth is about 1 percentage point lower and mean growth several percentage points lower compared with lower debt regimes

Finding for emerging market economies: high public debt (>90 percent of GDP) is associated with markedly lower median and mean GDP growth and with substantially higher inflation compared with lower debt regimes

Finding for external debt in emerging markets: lower thresholds apply—gross external debt above about 60 percent of GDP associates with sizable growth declines, and above 90 percent with very large growth reductions or outright declines; inflation rises mainly when external debt exceeds 90 percent

Evidence from 20 advanced countries: grouped annual observations into debt/GDP bins (below 30, 30–60, 60–90, above 90); 96 observations above 90 percent show median growth roughly 1 percent lower and mean almost 4 percent lower
Longer two-century sample for advanced countries yields similar averages: mean growth 1.7 percent when debt above 90 percent vs 3.7 percent when debt below 30 percent

Emerging market evidence: for 1900–2009 median GDP growth falls to about 2.9 percent when debt is above 90 percent while average growth falls to about 1 percent; per capita implications are as bad or worse due to faster population growth

Emerging market inflation evidence: median inflation more than doubles (from under 7 percent to about 16 percent) as public debt rises from below 30 percent to above 90 percent, consistent with fiscal dominance

External debt evidence: for selected emerging markets 1970–2009, growth deterioration begins when external debt exceeds 60 percent of GDP and deepens above 90 percent, with many defaults historically occurring at or above 60 percent

Observation on recent events: public debt rose sharply during the 2007–2009 global financial crisis, with crisis countries on average increasing central government debt by about 75 percent between 2007 and 2009 and other countries by about 20 percent

Private sector deleveraging after financial crises: private credit contracts following crises, which exacerbates downturns and is illustrated by US private debt/GDP declines after boom periods coinciding with lower growth and higher unemployment
Implication: the combined pattern of rising public debt and private deleveraging after crises suggests persistent medium-term growth headwinds following deep financial crises
Policy implication: debt management matters—reliance on short-term borrowing or shortening debt maturity increases vulnerability to sudden confidence crises and should be a public policy concern
Assumption and mechanism: nonlinear growth response to debt likely operates via rising market interest rates at debt tolerance limits, prompting fiscal adjustment, taxation, spending cuts, or default

Limitation: the analysis is empirical and descriptive and does not identify the genesis of debt buildups or fully establish causality; data on private domestic debt are scarcer and external debt series for advanced countries are too short to estimate long-run thresholds
